The [*trace*]{} $\operatorname{Tr}(A)$ of a square matrix $A$ is defined
to be the sum of the diagonal entries of $A$. It satisfies the following
formulas:

-   $\operatorname{Tr}(A+B) = \operatorname{Tr}(A) + \operatorname{Tr}(B)$

-   $\operatorname{Tr}(AB) = \operatorname{Tr}(BA)$()

where $A$ and $B$ are square matrices of the same size.

The [*trace*]{} $\operatorname{Tr}(T)$ of a linear transformation
$T\colon V \longrightarrow V$ from any finite dimensional vector space
$V$ to itself is defined to be the trace of any matrix representation of
$T$ with respect to a basis of $V$. This scalar is independent of the
choice of basis of $V$, and in fact is equal to the sum of the
eigenvalues of $T$ (over a splitting field of the characteristic
polynomial), including multiplicities.
